repnme.cdata!:
Dominican Republic - Financial Sector
            Technical Assistance Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Financial Sector
            Technical Assistance Loan (FSTAL) Project for Dominican
            Republic were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was high, the
            Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: during difficult times and when
            there is limited implementation capacity it is important to
            keep the design of a project simple even if the project is
            smaller. This project was too complex with multiple
            implementing agencies. Given the limited experience with
            financial sector operations in the Dominican Republic the
            FSTAL should have been structured as a simple project with
            clean implementation arrangements or alternatively with a
            longer execution period and a phased approach, in which
            triggers will be established for each phase of
            implementation. If successful, a follow up operation or
            phases of a longer duration project could have maintained
            the continuity of institutional support while being more
            responsive to changing technical assistance (TA) needs over
            time. The best indicator of project sustainability is
            borrower engagement in follow-up operations. The FSTAL tried
            to address too many challenges in the financial system but
            it should have been more selective particularly with the
            high degree of uncertainty at the time of project design.

5087402.majtheme: Rule of law,Financial and private sector development,Economic management

repnme.cdata!:
Dominican Republic - Financial Sector
            Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The first project development objective
            will consist of strengthening the institutional capacity of
            the monetary authorities to improve the design and
            implementation of monetary and fiscal policies. The project
            has the following ten components. Component 1) the Central
            Bank has generated an important quasi-fiscal deficit as a
            result of the banking crisis management. Component 2) focus
            on the areas of IT auditing function, external audits
            accountability, institutional strengthening, implementation
            of risk-focused supervision and full implementation of the
            off-site manual. Component 3) seeks to support a gradual
            development of the market through two major elements
            focusing on securities markets, and government debt
            management and fixed income markets. Component 4) will
            include review and update of the legislation; implementation
            of risk-based supervision; procurement of IT systems.
            Component 5) focuses on five areas where institutional
            capacity would be needed in the medium term: strategic
            planning, institutional development, human resource and IT
            and implementation; establishment of appropriate technical
            and regulatory framework for survivor and disability
            benefits; investment policy advice on appropriate
            regulations and linkages to other capital market reforms;
            training of supervisory staff and; creation of database and
            production of periodic reports in coordination with other
            agencies. Component 6) will support a comprehensive reform
            of the payments system, including the launch of safer and
            more efficient systems and an improved legal and oversight
            framework. Component 7) regulatory developments of the
            Monetary and Financial Law (LMF) include bank resolution and
            deposit insurance, penalties, consolidated supervision,
            capital adequacy, fit-and-proper criteria for bank managers
            and directors, loan classification and provisioning rules,
            adoption of market risk criteria, limits and enforcement of
            credit to related parties, adoption of best practices for
            corporate governance and strengthening of the bank's
            internal controls. Component 8) A draft law intended to
            change the functioning of the Ministry of Finance is
            currently being discussed in Congress. Component 9)
            Contingencies that could occur from an intensification of
            the banking crisis. Component 10) Financial Statements
            Audit. Hiring of a firm to audit the financial statements of
            the project.
